item.title: Blog with Jupyter Notebooks!
item.description:
from IPython.core.display import Image
Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png')


print("Welcome to Academic!")

Welcome to Academic!

Organize your notebooks

Place the notebooks that you would like to publish in a notebooks folder at the root of your website.

Import the notebooks into your site

pipx install academic
academic import 'notebooks/**.ipynb' content/post/ --verbose

The notebooks will be published to the folder you specify above. In this case, they will be published to your content/post/ folder.

item.title: Factors for Education Acheivement
item.description:
Data Exploration & Descriptive Analytics

Overview of data

The dataset are student results from the Big Five Personality questionnaire. According to the Big Five Personality model, the 5 personalities are Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Neuroticism, Openness and Extraversion (Goldberg, 1992).

The questionnaire is marked on a 5 point scale where 1=Disagree, 3=Neutral, 5=Agree (0=missed).

There are 382 records and 217 variables. All records are complete. 193 of the variables are text and 24 are integer. 1 record is an identifier.

(\#tab:read_data)Overview of data
Descriptions Value
Sample size (nrow) 382
No. of variables (ncol) 217
No. of numeric/interger variables 193
No. of factor variables 0
No. of text variables 24
No. of logical variables 0
No. of identifier variables 1
No. of date variables 0
No. of zero variance variables (uniform) 0
%. of variables having complete cases 100% (217)
%. of variables having >0% and <50% missing cases 0% (0)
%. of variables having >=50% and <90% missing cases 0% (0)
%. of variables having >=90% missing cases 0% (0)

211 P4 integer 382 0 0 6
212 P5 integer 382 0 0 6
213 P6 integer 382 0 0 6
214 P7 integer 382 0 0 6
215 P8 integer 382 0 0 6
216 P9 integer 382 0 0 6
217 P10 integer 382 0 0 6

Task Dimension reduction

Dimension reduction or feature selection is the process of selecting a subset of relevant features. The primary 3 reasons for using feature selection when constructing a model is that

  1. It improves the prediction performance of the predictors.
  2. Increases the performance of the model.
  3. Provides a better understanding of the underlying process that generated the data.

(Cunningham, 2008)

There are 3 primary methods to feature selection; filtering, using a wrapper method or embedded. Filtering is often univariate and considers the feature independently. The feature selection for our analysis will be a Principal Componenet Analysis (PCA) which is a wrapper method.

Hypothesis statement

H1: It is possible to measure the relationship between the selected factors and the manifest variables

H0: It is NOT possible to measure the relationship between selected factors and the manifest variables

Analysis plan

  • Select the 30 variables
  • Check correlations between variables using a correlation matrix plot.
  • Assess the Factorability of the data
    • Bartlett Test of Sphericity
    • Check KaiserMeyerOlkin (KMO)
  • Determine the number of factors to extract
  • Do the dimension reduction
  • Factor rotation
  • Accept if Cronbach Alpha > 0.7 for each component

Statistical Analysis

Variables

Variables chosen were results from the Extraversion (E), Agreeableness (A), and Neuroticism (N) questions.

reduction_t1 <- df[, c("A1", "A2", "A3", "A4", "A5","A6","A7", "A8", "A9", "A10",
                         "E1","E2", "E3", "E4", "E5", "E6","E7","E8", "E9","E10",
                         "N1", "N2", "N3", "N4", "N5", "N6", "N7", "N8", "N9", "N10")]

names(reduction_t1)

##  [1] "A1"  "A2"  "A3"  "A4"  "A5"  "A6"  "A7"  "A8"  "A9"  "A10" "E1"  "E2" 
## [13] "E3"  "E4"  "E5"  "E6"  "E7"  "E8"  "E9"  "E10" "N1"  "N2"  "N3"  "N4" 
## [25] "N5"  "N6"  "N7"  "N8"  "N9"  "N10"

Check correlations

The correlation matrix shows that for each personality the questions 1-7 are correlated with the other questions. However, question 8-10 are negatively correlated.

raqMatrix<-cor(reduction_t1)

#Using ggcorrplot. Note these are examples you need to choose a style for yourself, you do not need to create multiple correlation matrices
p.mat <- ggcorrplot::cor_pmat(reduction_t1)
ggcorrplot::ggcorrplot(raqMatrix, title = "Correlation matrix for RAQ data", p.mat = p.mat, sig.level = .05)

Assesing fatorability

The determinant of the R-matrix is an indicator of multicollinearity. Field et al. (2012). The detriment should be greater than 0.00001. In the selected variables the detriment is 1.1652257\times 10^{-5} which is greater than 0.00001.

Bartlett test

r_found <- cortest.bartlett(reduction_t1)
bartlett_test <- cortest.bartlett(raqMatrix, n=nrow(reduction_t1))

Bartletts test was statistically significant with a p value < 0.05. (0). The result suggests that the observed correlation matrix an identity matrix. However more tests are needed as this only tells us that we have some correlated variables.

Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin (KMO)

KMO is a better measure of factorability. The KMO tests to see if the partial correlations within your data are close enough to zero to suggest that there is at least one latent factor underlying in the variables. The minimum acceptable value is 0.50. The overall KMO for the data is 0.87 which is “meritorious” according to Kaiser

KMO(reduction_t1)

## Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin factor adequacy
## Call: KMO(r = reduction_t1)
## Overall MSA =  0.87
## MSA for each item = 
##   A1   A2   A3   A4   A5   A6   A7   A8   A9  A10   E1   E2   E3   E4   E5   E6 
## 0.88 0.92 0.82 0.87 0.89 0.88 0.89 0.82 0.88 0.71 0.92 0.88 0.77 0.89 0.86 0.81 
##   E7   E8   E9  E10   N1   N2   N3   N4   N5   N6   N7   N8   N9  N10 
## 0.66 0.87 0.77 0.68 0.90 0.91 0.89 0.90 0.91 0.87 0.92 0.88 0.87 0.88

Determining the number of factors to extract

Eigenvalues are a measure of the amount of variance accounted for by a factor. They are useful for determining the number of factors we should extract. The below screeplot suggests that we should extract 6 factors and 4 components. Factors with eigen values less than 1 are not meaningful.

pcf=princomp(reduction_t1)

pc1 <-  principal(reduction_t1, nfactors = 6, rotate = "none")

pc1$values

##  [1] 6.9296903 3.4959469 2.3724888 1.6147360 1.2643404 1.1683380 0.9877006
##  [8] 0.9316453 0.8814789 0.8081575 0.7949578 0.7469015 0.6840229 0.6438069
## [15] 0.5974493 0.5610605 0.5522671 0.5401232 0.5047079 0.4525625 0.4277723
## [22] 0.4136199 0.4048166 0.3988665 0.3426954 0.3334239 0.3192452 0.2989060
## [29] 0.2722950 0.2559767

scree_1 <- scree(reduction_t1)

Dimension Reduction (PCA)

The six factor solution is not easily explained. From the diagram there are 2 major loading’s. We will look to reduce the number of factors from 6 to 3 and apply rotation to refine the component structure. Reducing the factors will allow for better explainability.

fa.diagram(pc1)

Using the eigenvalues we can compute the percentage of variance associated with each of the factors. The variables with the red dotted line show that they are negatively correlated.

pc2 <-  principal(reduction_t1, nfactors = 3, rotate = "varimax")
100*pc2$values[1:3]/length(pc2$values)

## [1] 23.098968 11.653156  7.908296

fa.diagram(pc2)

Below is the percentage of variance that can be explained by the retained factors for each variable.

pc2$communality

##         A1         A2         A3         A4         A5         A6         A7 
## 0.53289913 0.56278655 0.50490456 0.39070531 0.43166518 0.49643485 0.34871948 
##         A8         A9        A10         E1         E2         E3         E4 
## 0.32100149 0.48196078 0.32669935 0.56528812 0.69462271 0.39529788 0.62001308 
##         E5         E6         E7         E8         E9        E10         N1 
## 0.49229005 0.36425908 0.13017062 0.45963285 0.12275607 0.08024035 0.50920362 
##         N2         N3         N4         N5         N6         N7         N8 
## 0.48976850 0.58124245 0.55080984 0.39731616 0.54862087 0.37252444 0.48120948 
##         N9        N10 
## 0.28594288 0.25914038

Reliability

The first component has a Cronbachs of 0.84 which indicates a good reliability, Kline (1999)

#If you know that variables are grouped, test each group as a separate scale

neuroticism <- reduction_t1[,c("N1", "N2", "N3", "N4", "N5", "N6", "N7","E8","N10")]
agreeable <- reduction_t1[,c("A1", "A2", "A3", "A4", "A5","A6","A7", "A9")]
extraversion <- reduction_t1[,c("E1","E2", "E3", "E4", "E5", "E6", "N9", "N8")]

neuroticism <- alpha(neuroticism, keys = c(1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, -1))
agreeable <- alpha(agreeable, keys = c(1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, -1))
extraversion <- alpha(extraversion)

summary(neuroticism)

## 
## Reliability analysis   
##  raw_alpha std.alpha G6(smc) average_r S/N   ase mean   sd median_r
##       0.84      0.85    0.84      0.38 5.5 0.012  3.4 0.77     0.37

The second component has a Cronbachs of 0.82

summary(agreeable)

## 
## Reliability analysis   
##  raw_alpha std.alpha G6(smc) average_r S/N   ase mean   sd median_r
##       0.82      0.82    0.82      0.37 4.6 0.014  3.7 0.66     0.37

The third component has a Cronbachs of 0.81

summary(extraversion)

## 
## Reliability analysis   
##  raw_alpha std.alpha G6(smc) average_r S/N   ase mean   sd median_r
##       0.81      0.81    0.83      0.35 4.3 0.014  3.2 0.77     0.32

Results

A principal component analysis (PCA) was conducted on the 30 items with orthogonal rotation (varimax). Bartletts test of sphericity, 2(382) = 1.1652257^{-5} , p< .001, indicated that correlations between items were sufficiently large for PCA.

An initial analysis was run to obtain eigenvalues for each component in the data. Six components had eigenvalues over Kaisers criterion of 1 and in combination explained 56.1518015 of the variance. The scree plot was slightly ambiguous and showed inflections that would justify retaining either 6 or 3 factors. Given the large sample size, and the convergence of the scree plot and Kaisers criterion on three components, three components were retained in the final analysis. Component 1 represents a neuroticism, component 2 agreeableness, and component 3 extraversion.

All 3 personality traits from the Big Five Personality questionnaire had high reliabilities. Neuroticism cronbachs = 0.84. Agreeableness cronbachs = 0.82. Extraversion = 0.81.

Therefore, we reject the null hypothesis.

Task Linear Regression

For the linear regression we will use the academic performance data.

Multiple linear regression are linear regression models that are used to build a linear relationship between one response or dependent variable and more than one predictor or independent variable.

The dependent variable is CC_S11, it is a numeric interval variable with values between 0 and 100, it is the result of an exam. The predictor variables are INTERNET, CR_S11 CC_PRO. INTERNET is a binary variable, ‘yes’ indicating that a student has access to internet and ’no’ that a student does not. CC_PRO and CR_S11 are exam result between the values of 0 and 100.

It is expected that students that have access to internet and have performed well in Citizen Competencies saber pro and critical reading saber 11 exam should perform better in the Citizen Competencies saber 11 exams than students who do not have access to internet and performed poorly in the Citizen Competencies saber pro exam.

(\#tab:read_data_2)Overview of data
Descriptions Value
Sample size (nrow) 12411
No. of variables (ncol) 48
No. of numeric/interger variables 30
No. of factor variables 0
No. of text variables 17
No. of logical variables 1
No. of identifier variables 1
No. of date variables 0
No. of zero variance variables (uniform) 0
%. of variables having complete cases 81.25% (39)
%. of variables having >0% and <50% missing cases 16.67% (8)
%. of variables having >=50% and <90% missing cases 0% (0)
%. of variables having >=90% missing cases 2.08% (1)

Hypothesis statement

H1: There will be a significant prediction of a students exam score CC_S11by a students access to theINTERNET and their result in CC_PRO and CR_S11O

H0: There will be no significant prediction of a students exam score CC_S11by a students access to the INTERNET and their result in CC_PRO and CR_S11

Analysis plan

  • Create dummy variable for INTERNET (no being the reference category and 1 being the category of interest)
  • Explore selected variables
  • Create the model
  • Test the assumptions

Statistical Analysis

Explore variables

The scatter plots show that there is a positive relationship between the dependent variable and each of the predictors individually.

Note In the previous assignment we determined that there was correlation between each of the predictors and the dependent variable.

scatter_plot_func <- function(data, col){
  
 ggplot(df, aes(x=CC_S11, y=.data[[col]])) +
    geom_point() +
    geom_smooth(method=lm) +
    labs(x = col, y='CC_S11') +
    theme_minimal() 
  
}


selected_variables <- names(select(df, 'INTERNET', 'CC_PRO', 'CR_S11'))
scatter_plot_list <- list()


scatter_plot_list <- lapply(selected_variables, scatter_plot_func, data = df)
plot_grob <- arrangeGrob(grobs=scatter_plot_list)
grid.arrange(plot_grob)

Model

Below we created 3 models. The R squared and adjusted R squared increases as we add more variables. However the adjusted R and multiple R squared can increase with more predictors and is not enough reason to reject the null hypothesis.

Internet as a predictor is not statistically significant, while CR_S11 (0.002) and CC_PRO (0.007) are statistically significant.

The residual standard error is lower as we add predictors, only slightly when adding internet, indicating that the predicted values of the model are getting closer to the actual values when adding more predictors.

The F statistic shows that each of the models as a whole are statistically significant.

model1<-lm(df$CC_S11 ~ df$CC_PRO + df$INTERNET + df$CR_S11)
#stargazer::stargazer(model1, type="text") #Tidy output of all the required stats

m1 <- lm(CC_S11 ~ CC_PRO, data=df)
m2 <- lm(CC_S11 ~ CC_PRO + INTERNET, data=df)
m3 <- lm(CC_S11 ~ CC_PRO + INTERNET + CR_S11, data=df)
stargazer::stargazer(m1, m2, m3, type="text",
 dep.var.labels=c("Citizen Compenticies Saber 11 exam"),
 covariate.labels=c("Citizen Compenticies Saber pro exam","Internet Access (1=yes)","Critical Reading Saber 11 exam"), title="Results", align=TRUE)

## 
## Results
## ==========================================================================================================================
##                                                                      Dependent variable:                                  
##                                     --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
##                                                               Citizen Compenticies Saber 11 exam                          
##                                                 (1)                          (2)                          (3)             
## --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Citizen Compenticies Saber pro exam           0.183***                     0.181***                     0.070***          
##                                               (0.003)                      (0.003)                      (0.002)           
##                                                                                                                           
## Internet Access (1=yes)                                                    1.477***                      0.108            
##                                                                            (0.189)                      (0.148)           
##                                                                                                                           
## Critical Reading Saber 11 exam                                                                          0.633***          
##                                                                                                         (0.007)           
##                                                                                                                           
## Constant                                     49.875***                    48.850***                    17.994***          
##                                               (0.176)                      (0.219)                      (0.382)           
##                                                                                                                           
## --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Observations                                   12,411                       12,411                       12,411           
## R2                                             0.275                        0.278                        0.564            
## Adjusted R2                                    0.275                        0.278                        0.564            
## Residual Std. Error                      8.619 (df = 12409)           8.598 (df = 12408)           6.682 (df = 12407)     
## F Statistic                         4,701.952*** (df = 1; 12409) 2,392.759*** (df = 2; 12408) 5,354.543*** (df = 3; 12407)
## ==========================================================================================================================
## Note:                                                                                          *p<0.1; **p<0.05; ***p<0.01

Assess whether model meets key assumptions of linear regression

The diagnostic plots show that outliers exist. These outliers can cause a type 1 error.

par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(m3)

The below plot is using cooks distance on the model which finds records that are 4 times greater than the mean.

Below that are some examples of records which are causing the outliers in the model.

For example, in the record 8122 a student who scored 98 and 74 in the CC_PRO and CR_S11 exams respectively with no internet only achieved 62 in the CC_S11 exam.

new_df <- (select(df, 'CC_S11', 'INTERNET', 'CC_PRO', 'CR_S11'))
#Influential Outliers - Cook's distance
cooksd<-sort(cooks.distance(m3))
# plot Cook's distance
plot(cooksd, pch="*", cex=2, main="Influential Obs by Cooks distance")  
abline(h = 4*mean(cooksd, na.rm=T), col="red")  # add cutoff line
text(x=1:length(cooksd)+1, y=cooksd, labels=ifelse(cooksd>4*mean(cooksd, na.rm=T),names(cooksd),""), col="red")  # add labels

#find rows related to influential observations
influential <- as.numeric(names(cooksd)[(cooksd > 4*mean(cooksd, na.rm=T))])  # influential row numbers
#stem(influential)
head(new_df[influential, ])  # influential observations.

##       CC_S11 INTERNET CC_PRO CR_S11
## 12094     75        0     95     63
## 1803      35        1     36     41
## 8687      41        1     18     57
## 488       65        1     72     47
## 8122      62        0     98     74
## 8264      77        1     86     58

#head(df[influential, ]$CC_S11)  # influential observations - look at the values of tpcoiss
#head(df[influential, ]$CC_PRO)  # influential observations - look at the values of optimism
#head(df[influential, ]$INTERNET)  # influential observations -look at the values of marlow

The following density and qq plots below show that the residuals are normally distributed. The QQ plot shows that there is a positive skew in the residuals.

#Assess homocedasticity 
plot(m3, 3)

#This is model1 much better result than model 1

#A density plot of the residuals
plot(density(resid(m3))) 

#Create a QQ plot qPlot(model, main="QQ Plot") #qq plot for studentized resid 
car::qqPlot(m3, main="QQ Plot Model 3") #qq plot for studentized resid

## [1]  2013 11400

Tests to see if the data met the assumption of collinearity indicated that multicollinearity was not a concern (CC_PRO,Tolerance = .73,VIF = 1.36; INTERNET, Tolerance = 1.02 VIF = .98; CR_S11=.73,VIF=1.38).

#Collinearity
vifmodel<-car::vif(m3)
vifmodel

##   CC_PRO INTERNET   CR_S11 
## 1.364411 1.022923 1.376509

#Tolerance
1/vifmodel

##    CC_PRO  INTERNET    CR_S11 
## 0.7329171 0.9775908 0.7264752

Results

A multiple regression analysis was conducted to determine if a students score in CC_PRO and CR_S11O and whether they had access to internet could predict a students exam score CC_S11.

In order to include whether a student had access to the internet in the regression model it was recorded a dummy variable INTERNET (0 for no, 1 for yes)

Examination of the histogram, normal P-P plot of standardised residuals and the scatterplot of the dependent variable,exam score CC_S11, and standardised residuals showed that outliers existed. However, examination of the standardised residuals showed that none could be considered to have undue influence (95% within limits of -1.96 to plus 1.96 and none with Cooks distance >1 as outlined in Field (2013).

Examination for multicollinearity showed that the tolerance and variance influence factor measures were within acceptable levels (tolerance >0.4, VIF <2.5 ) as outlined in Tarling (2008). The scatterplot of standardised residuals showed that the data met the assumptions of homogeneity of variance and linearity. The data also meets the assumption of non-zero variances of the predictors.

The Null hypothesis was rejected as the model as a whole (significant F statistic) was significant. However, a student’s access to the internet combined with other predictors was not shown to be significant in predicting a students result in CC_S11.

Task Logistic Regression

Logistic regression is to predict an outcome variable that is categorical (nominal) from one or more categorical (nominal) or continuous (interval or ratio) predictor variables.

The dependent variable is SCHOOL_NAT, it is a binary variable specifying whether the student went to a public or private school. The predictor variables are CR_S11 and CC_PRO and EDU_FATHER. CC_PRO and CR_S11 is an exam result between the values of 0 and 100. EDU_FATHER is a categorical variable specifying the highest level of formal education the father of the student achieved.

Students that have come from a private school are expected to have performed well in these exams due to their advantage. Students with a father that completed a higher level of education are thought to be more likely to have gone to a private school.

Hypothesis statement

H1: There will be a significant prediction on what type of school a student came from based on their CC_PRO and CR_S11 exam results and whether their father completed a high level of education.

H0: There will be no significant prediction on what type of school a student came from based on their CC_PRO and CR_S11 exam results andwhether their father completed a high level of education.

Analysis plan

  • Explore selected variables
  • Create the model
  • Test the assumptions

Statistical Analysis

Explore variables

The box plots show can that students who attended a private school have on average performed better than students that attended a public school.

The mosaic plot shows that students who’s father completed post graduate education were more likely to have attended a private school.

box_plot_func <- function(data, col){
  
 ggplot(df, aes(x=SCHOOL_NAT, y=data[[col]], fill=SCHOOL_NAT)) +
    geom_boxplot() +
    labs(y = col ) +
    theme_minimal() 
  
}


selected_variables <- names(select(df, 'CC_PRO', 'CR_S11'))
box_plot_list <- list()


box_plot_list <- lapply(selected_variables, box_plot_func, data = df)
plot_grob <- arrangeGrob(grobs=box_plot_list)
grid.arrange(plot_grob)

mosaicplot(EDU_FATHER~SCHOOL_NAT,data=df,col=c("Blue","Red"))

Model

3 models were created. The best fitting model is the third with 3 predictors, selected due to the lower Akaike Information Criterion (AIC).

The decrease in AIC it is worth having the extra predictor. It may be better to have not used CC_PRO as a predictor due to a small decrease in AIC however.

df<-as.data.frame(df)
df <- df[,colSums(is.na(df))<nrow(df)]
df<-na.omit(df)
df$SCHOOL_NAT <- as.integer(plyr::mapvalues(df$SCHOOL_NAT, from=c('PRIVATE', 'PUBLIC'), to=c(1,0)))
# categorical variables as factors. 
df$SCHOOL_NAT <- as.factor(df$SCHOOL_NAT)
education_levels <- c("Postgraduate education", "Post Secondary", "Secondary", "Primary", "None")
education_levels <- rev(education_levels)

df$EDU_FATHER <- factor(df$EDU_FATHER, ordered = TRUE, 
                                levels = education_levels)

logmodel1 <- glm(SCHOOL_NAT ~ CC_PRO, data = df, na.action = na.exclude, family = binomial(link=logit))
logmodel2 <- glm(SCHOOL_NAT ~ CC_PRO+CR_S11, data = df, na.action = na.exclude, family = binomial(link=logit))
logmodel3 <- glm(SCHOOL_NAT ~ CC_PRO+CR_S11+EDU_FATHER, data = df, na.action = na.exclude, family = binomial(link=logit))

stargazer::stargazer(logmodel1, logmodel2, logmodel3, type="text",
 dep.var.labels=c("School Type"),
 covariate.labels=c("Citizen Compenticies Saber pro exam","Critical Reading Saber 11 exam", "Fathers Education Level"), title="Results", align=TRUE)

## 
## Results
## ====================================================================
##                                           Dependent variable:       
##                                     --------------------------------
##                                               School Type           
##                                        (1)        (2)        (3)    
## --------------------------------------------------------------------
## Citizen Compenticies Saber pro exam  0.010***   0.004***   0.002**  
##                                      (0.001)    (0.001)    (0.001)  
##                                                                     
## Critical Reading Saber 11 exam                  0.036***   0.027*** 
##                                                 (0.002)    (0.002)  
##                                                                     
## Fathers Education Level                                    2.152*** 
##                                                            (0.081)  
##                                                                     
## EDU_FATHER.Q                                               0.271*** 
##                                                            (0.071)  
##                                                                     
## EDU_FATHER.C                                              -0.174*** 
##                                                            (0.055)  
##                                                                     
## EDU_FATHER4                                                 -0.021  
##                                                            (0.041)  
##                                                                     
## Constant                            -0.503***  -2.312***  -1.798*** 
##                                      (0.044)    (0.127)    (0.137)  
##                                                                     
## --------------------------------------------------------------------
## Observations                          10,996     10,996     10,996  
## Log Likelihood                      -7,507.251 -7,384.876 -6,728.260
## Akaike Inf. Crit.                   15,018.500 14,775.750 13,470.520
## ====================================================================
## Note:                                    *p<0.1; **p<0.05; ***p<0.01

The Pr(>|z|) column shows us that each of the predictors are statistically significant in the model (>0.05). The z statistic shows us that each of the predictors have a positive direction, meaning that when a students exam result is higher then therefore they are more likely to have gone to a private school (1=private school, 0=public).

summary(logmodel3)

## 
## Call:
## glm(formula = SCHOOL_NAT ~ CC_PRO + CR_S11 + EDU_FATHER, family = binomial(link = logit), 
##     data = df, na.action = na.exclude)
## 
## Deviance Residuals: 
##     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max  
## -2.2369  -1.0235   0.5556   0.9624   2.0619  
## 
## Coefficients:
##               Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
## (Intercept)  -1.798381   0.136730 -13.153  < 2e-16 ***
## CC_PRO        0.002065   0.000832   2.482 0.013049 *  
## CR_S11        0.027055   0.002473  10.938  < 2e-16 ***
## EDU_FATHER.L  2.152224   0.080708  26.667  < 2e-16 ***
## EDU_FATHER.Q  0.271170   0.070529   3.845 0.000121 ***
## EDU_FATHER.C -0.174381   0.055455  -3.145 0.001663 ** 
## EDU_FATHER^4 -0.021074   0.041487  -0.508 0.611486    
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)
## 
##     Null deviance: 15229  on 10995  degrees of freedom
## Residual deviance: 13457  on 10989  degrees of freedom
## AIC: 13471
## 
## Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4

From visualizing the results we can see that as the level education of the father is higher the more likely it is that the student came from a private school.

Below are pseudo R2 test statistics showing how useful the model. In this case they indicate that that between 3% and 5% of the variability of students went to private school.

visreg::visreg(logmodel3, xvar = "EDU_FATHER", data = df, scale = "response")

DescTools::PseudoR2(logmodel2, which="CoxSnell")

##  CoxSnell 
## 0.0409042

DescTools::PseudoR2(logmodel2, which="Nagelkerke")

## Nagelkerke 
## 0.05456326

An AUC of 0.726 inidcates that the model is decent classifier of whether a student came from a private school.

df$EDU_FATHER_D <- as.integer(plyr::mapvalues(df$EDU_FATHER, from=education_levels, to=c(5,4,3,2,1)))

prob=predict(logmodel3,type=c("response"))
df$prob=prob

g <- roc(SCHOOL_NAT ~ prob, data = df, plot = TRUE, print.auc = TRUE)

g

## 
## Call:
## roc.formula(formula = SCHOOL_NAT ~ prob, data = df, plot = TRUE,     print.auc = TRUE)
## 
## Data: prob in 5297 controls (SCHOOL_NAT 0) < 5699 cases (SCHOOL_NAT 1).
## Area under the curve: 0.726

The model had an accuracy of 66.47% with a misclassification rate of 33.53%.

The sensitivity of the model was 0.68 while the specificity was 0.65. The model is ok but there are quite a lot of false negatives and false positives.

cm

##          Predicted 0 Predicted 1 Total
## Actual 0        3468        1829  5297
## Actual 1        1858        3841  5699
## Total           5326        5670 10996

Assess whether model meets key assumptions of linear regression

The Hosmer-Lemeshow test (HL test) is a goodness of fit test for binary classification models which tells how well data fits a given model. Hosmer Lemeshow goodness of fit statistic did indicate issues with the assumption of linearity between the independent variables and the log odds of the model (2 (n=8)=20.445, p=0.009). The P value is less than < 0.05 and therefore statistically signifigant.

#Check the assumption of linearity of independent variables and log odds using a Hosmer-Lemeshow test, if this is not statistically significant we are ok

generalhoslem::logitgof(df$SCHOOL_NAT, fitted(logmodel3))

## 
## 	Hosmer and Lemeshow test (binary model)
## 
## data:  df$SCHOOL_NAT, fitted(logmodel3)
## X-squared = 20.445, df = 8, p-value = 0.008777

#Collinearity
vifmodel<-car::vif(logmodel3)#You can ignore the warning messages, GVIF^(1/(2*Df)) is the value of interest
vifmodel

##                GVIF Df GVIF^(1/(2*Df))
## CC_PRO     1.331664  1        1.153978
## CR_S11     1.336841  1        1.156218
## EDU_FATHER 1.014507  4        1.001802

#Tolerance
1/vifmodel

##                 GVIF   Df GVIF^(1/(2*Df))
## CC_PRO     0.7509401 1.00       0.8665680
## CR_S11     0.7480320 1.00       0.8648884
## EDU_FATHER 0.9857000 0.25       0.9982012

Results

A binary logistic regression analysis was conducted with a students previous school type as the outcome variable (Private or Public) with the student’s fathers education as well as their results in CC_PRO and CR_S11 exams as predictors.

The data met the assumption for independent observations.

Examination for multicollinearity showed that the tolerance and variance influence factor measures were within acceptable levels (tolerance >0.4, VIF <2.5 ) as outlined in Tarling (2008).

Hosmer Lemeshow goodness of fit statistic did indicate issues with the assumption of linearity between the independent variables and the log odds of the model (2 (n=8)=20.445, p=0.009).

Due to the fail in Hosmer Lemeshow goodness of fit we accept the null hypothesis.

Task Compare models

In the linear regression models created we saw that access to internet was a weak predictor of the exam result CC_S11.

For this we will compare the original model with a new model without the variable INTERNET, to see if it gives a better fit.

Statistical Analysis

When comparing the two models we see that the adjusted R2 hasn’t moved when adding INTERNET as a variable. This shows that internet does not offer any increase in the variance explained for the dependent variable.

The F statistic is more significant in the model without internet indicating the model is more significant as a whole for predicting a students CC_S11 exam result.

model1<-lm(df$CC_S11 ~ df$CC_PRO + df$INTERNET + df$CR_S11)
#stargazer::stargazer(model1, type="text") #Tidy output of all the required stats

m1 <- lm(CC_S11 ~ CC_PRO + CR_S11, data=df)
m2 <- lm(CC_S11 ~ CC_PRO + CR_S11 + INTERNET , data=df)

stargazer::stargazer(m1, m2, type="text",
 dep.var.labels=c("Citizen Compenticies Saber 11 exam"),
 covariate.labels=c("Citizen Compenticies Saber pro exam","Critical Reading Saber 11 exam","Internet Access (1=yes)"), title="Results", align=TRUE)

## 
## Results
## =============================================================================================
##                                                        Dependent variable:                   
##                                     ---------------------------------------------------------
##                                                Citizen Compenticies Saber 11 exam            
##                                                 (1)                          (2)             
## ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Citizen Compenticies Saber pro exam           0.072***                     0.072***          
##                                               (0.003)                      (0.003)           
##                                                                                              
## Critical Reading Saber 11 exam                0.629***                     0.629***          
##                                               (0.007)                      (0.007)           
##                                                                                              
## Internet Access (1=yes)                                                     0.100            
##                                                                            (0.159)           
##                                                                                              
## Constant                                     18.302***                    18.257***          
##                                               (0.402)                      (0.409)           
##                                                                                              
## ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Observations                                   10,996                       10,996           
## R2                                             0.561                        0.561            
## Adjusted R2                                    0.561                        0.561            
## Residual Std. Error                      6.745 (df = 10993)           6.745 (df = 10992)     
## F Statistic                         7,016.276*** (df = 2; 10993) 4,677.394*** (df = 3; 10992)
## =============================================================================================
## Note:                                                             *p<0.1; **p<0.05; ***p<0.01

Check assumptions

Checking for outliers

## [1] 562

## [1] 551

Using cooks distance the model with INTERNET has 562 outliers while the model without has 551 outliers.

Checking for homocedasticity

Like the model with internet, the residuals of the new model follows a normal distribution with a slight positive skew.

#Assess homocedasticity 
plot(m1, 3)

#This is model1 much better result than model 1

#A density plot of the residuals
plot(density(resid(m1))) 

#Create a QQ plot qPlot(model, main="QQ Plot") #qq plot for studentized resid 
car::qqPlot(m1, main="QQ Plot Model without Internet") #qq plot for studentized resid

##  6336 11400 
##  5118 10012

Tests to see if the data met the assumption of collinearity indicated that multicollinearity was not a concern (CC_PRO,Tolerance = .74,VIF = 1.36; CR_S11=.74,VIF=1.36).

#Collinearity
vifmodel<-car::vif(m1)
vifmodel

##  CC_PRO  CR_S11 
## 1.36244 1.36244

#Tolerance
1/vifmodel

##   CC_PRO   CR_S11 
## 0.733977 0.733977

Conclusion

A better model to choose for predicting the exam result of CC_S11, is the model without INTERNET.

The reasons are:

  • The model is less complex (had one less variable)
  • The model was more significant as a whole.
  • The explained variance (adjusted R2) did not increase when INTERNET was added as a predictor.
  • The model had less outliers

Refrences

  • Goldberg, Lewis R. “The development of markers for the Big-Five factor structure.” Psychological assessment 4.1 (1992): 26. Retrieved from here

  • Field, A., Miles, J., & Field, Z. (2012). Discovering statistics with R. Sage Publications Ltd.

  • Kline, P. (1999). The handbook of psychological testing (2nd ed.). London: Routledge.

  • Cunningham, P. (2008). Dimension Reduction. In: Cord, M., Cunningham, P. (eds) Machine Learning Techniques for Multimedia. Cognitive Technologies. Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-540-75171-7_4 Retrieved from here

  • Field et al (2012). Reliabilty analysis Tutorial. Retrieved from here

  • Kumar (2022). Linear regression hypothesis testing: Concepts, Examples. Retrieved from here

  • Hlavac (2022). stargazer: beautiful LATEX, HTML and ASCII tables from R statistical output. Retrieved from here

item.title: Welcome to Hugo Blox Builder, the website builder for Hugo
item.description:
import libr
print('hello')

Overview

  1. The Wowchemy website builder for Hugo, along with its starter templates, is designed for professional creators, educators, and teams/organizations - although it can be used to create any kind of site
  2. The template can be modified and customised to suit your needs. It’s a good platform for anyone looking to take control of their data and online identity whilst having the convenience to start off with a no-code solution (write in Markdown and customize with YAML parameters) and having flexibility to later add even deeper personalization with HTML and CSS
  3. You can work with all your favourite tools and apps with hundreds of plugins and integrations to speed up your workflows, interact with your readers, and much more

Get Started

  • Create a new site
  • Personalize your site
  • Chat with the Wowchemy community or Hugo community
  • Twitter: @wowchemy @GeorgeCushen #MadeWithWowchemy
  • Request a feature or report a bug for Wowchemy
  • Updating Wowchemy? View the Update Tutorial and Release Notes

Crowd-funded open-source software

To help us develop this template and software sustainably under the MIT license, we ask all individuals and businesses that use it to help support its ongoing maintenance and development via sponsorship.

Click here to become a sponsor and help support Wowchemy’s future

As a token of appreciation for sponsoring, you can unlock these awesome rewards and extra features

Ecosystem

  • Hugo Academic CLI: Automatically import publications from BibTeX

Inspiration

Check out the latest demo of what you’ll get in less than 10 minutes, or view the showcase of personal, project, and business sites.

Features

  • Page builder - Create anything with widgets and elements
  • Edit any type of content - Blog posts, publications, talks, slides, projects, and more!
  • Create content in Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio
  • Plugin System - Fully customizable color and font themes
  • Display Code and Math - Code highlighting and LaTeX math supported
  • Integrations - Google Analytics, Disqus commenting, Maps, Contact Forms, and more!
  • Beautiful Site - Simple and refreshing one page design
  • Industry-Leading SEO - Help get your website found on search engines and social media
  • Media Galleries - Display your images and videos with captions in a customizable gallery
  • Mobile Friendly - Look amazing on every screen with a mobile friendly version of your site
  • Multi-language - 34+ language packs including English, , and Portugus
  • Multi-user - Each author gets their own profile page
  • Privacy Pack - Assists with GDPR
  • Stand Out - Bring your site to life with animation, parallax backgrounds, and scroll effects
  • One-Click Deployment - No servers. No databases. Only files.

Themes

Wowchemy and its templates come with automatic day (light) and night (dark) mode built-in. Alternatively, visitors can choose their preferred mode - click the moon icon in the top right of the Demo to see it in action! Day/night mode can also be disabled by the site admin in params.toml.

Choose a stunning theme and font for your site. Themes are fully customizable.

License

Copyright 2016-present George Cushen.

Released under the MIT license.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description:
R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)
##      speed           dist       
##  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
##  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
##  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
##  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
##  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
##  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
fit
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)        speed  
##     -17.579        3.932

Including Plots

You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)

Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.

item.title: Writing technical content in Markdown
item.description:
Hugo Blox Builder is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Wowchemy handles the rest.

Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.

On this page, you’ll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Wowchemy.

Examples

Code

Wowchemy supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can customize the styles under the syntax_highlighter option in your config/_default/params.yaml file.

```python
import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()
```

renders as

import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()

Mindmaps

Wowchemy supports a Markdown extension for mindmaps.

Simply insert a Markdown markmap code block and optionally set the height of the mindmap as shown in the example below.

A simple mindmap defined as a Markdown list:


```markmap {height="200px"}
- Hugo Modules
  - wowchemy
  - blox-plugins-netlify
  - blox-plugins-netlify-cms
  - blox-plugins-reveal
```

renders as

- Hugo Modules
  - wowchemy
  - blox-plugins-netlify
  - blox-plugins-netlify-cms
  - blox-plugins-reveal

A more advanced mindmap with formatting, code blocks, and math:


```markmap
- Mindmaps
  - Links
    - [Wowchemy Docs](https://docs.hugoblox.com/)
    - [Discord Community](https://discord.gg/z8wNYzb)
    - [GitHub](https://github.com/HugoBlox/hugo-blox-builder)
  - Features
    - Markdown formatting
    - **inline** ~~text~~ *styles*
    - multiline
      text
    - `inline code`
    -
      ```js
      console.log('hello');
      console.log('code block');
      ```
    - Math: $x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}$
```

renders as

- Mindmaps
  - Links
    - [Wowchemy Docs](https://docs.hugoblox.com/)
    - [Discord Community](https://discord.gg/z8wNYzb)
    - [GitHub](https://github.com/HugoBlox/hugo-blox-builder)
  - Features
    - Markdown formatting
    - **inline** ~~text~~ *styles*
    - multiline
      text
    - `inline code`
    -
      ```js
      console.log('hello');
      console.log('code block');
      ```
    - Math: $x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}$

Charts

Wowchemy supports the popular Plotly format for interactive charts.

Save your Plotly JSON in your page folder, for example line-chart.json, and then add the {{< chart data="line-chart" >}} shortcode where you would like the chart to appear.

Demo:

You might also find the Plotly JSON Editor useful.

Math

Wowchemy supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.yaml file.

To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with {{< math >}}$...${{< /math >}} or {{< math >}}$$...$${{< /math >}}, respectively. (We wrap the LaTeX math in the Wowchemy math shortcode to prevent Hugo rendering our math as Markdown. The math shortcode is new in v5.5-dev.)

Example math block:

{{< math >}}
$$
\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}
$$
{{< /math >}}

renders as

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$

Example inline math {{< math >}}$\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})${{< /math >}} renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.

Example multi-line math using the math linebreak (\\):

{{< math >}}
$$f(k;p_{0}^{*}) = \begin{cases}p_{0}^{*} & \text{if }k=1, \\
1-p_{0}^{*} & \text{if }k=0.\end{cases}$$
{{< /math >}}

renders as

$$ f(k;p_{0}^{*}) = \begin{cases}p_{0}^{*} & \text{if }k=1, \\ 1-p_{0}^{*} & \text{if }k=0.\end{cases} $$

Diagrams

Wowchemy supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.

An example flowchart:

```mermaid
graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]
```

renders as

graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2]

An example sequence diagram:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!
```

renders as

sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good!

An example Gantt diagram:

```mermaid
gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d
```

renders as

gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d

An example class diagram:

```mermaid
classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
Class03 *-- Class04
Class05 o-- Class06
Class07 .. Class08
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
Class08 <--> C2: Cool label
```

renders as

classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool Class03 *-- Class04 Class05 o-- Class06 Class07 .. Class08 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla Class08 <--> C2: Cool label

An example state diagram:

```mermaid
stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]
```

renders as

stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*]

Todo lists

You can even write your todo lists in Markdown too:

- [x] Write math example
  - [x] Write diagram example
- [ ] Do something else

renders as

  • Write math example
    • Write diagram example
  • Do something else

Tables

Save your spreadsheet as a CSV file in your page’s folder and then render it by adding the Table shortcode to your page:

{{< table path="results.csv" header="true" caption="Table 1: My results" >}}

renders as

customer_id score
1 0
2 0.5
3 1
Table 1: My results

Callouts

Academic supports a shortcode for callouts, also referred to as asides, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% callout note %}} ... {{% /callout %}}, it will render as an aside.

{{% callout note %}}
A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.
{{% /callout %}}

renders as

A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.

Spoilers

Add a spoiler to a page to reveal text, such as an answer to a question, after a button is clicked.

{{< spoiler text="Click to view the spoiler" >}}
You found me!
{{< /spoiler >}}

renders as

Click to view the spoiler

You found me!

Icons

Academic enables you to use a wide range of icons from Font Awesome and Academicons in addition to emojis.

Here are some examples using the icon shortcode to render icons:

{{< icon name="terminal" pack="fas" >}} Terminal  
{{< icon name="python" pack="fab" >}} Python  
{{< icon name="r-project" pack="fab" >}} R

renders as

Terminal
Python
R

Did you find this page helpful? Consider sharing it
